awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2021: Effects of individual experience  on population social structure: integrating development, gene expression and social  ecology
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2021, Integrative Research Investigating the Rules of Life Governing Interactions Between Genomes, Environment and Phenotypes. The fellowship supports research and training of the fellow that will contribute to the area of Rules of Life in innovative ways. All societies are made up of individuals and their complex set of characteristics and interactions. At the same time, individuals’ health and behavior in adulthood are shaped by the social and physical experiences of early life. Yet, it remains unclear how these early life experiences shape higher level social structure. The fellow will use semi-natural populations of mice to fill this gap by studying how variation in individuals’ previous experiences and resulting behavior in adulthood collectively shape the structure of the larger society in which they live. In addition to the research outcomes from this work, the fellow will continue to develop two projects that improve and expand the dissemination of research in the areas of animal behavior, life history, and evolution. The first project is the Long-Term Animal Research seminar series, an innovative virtual seminar series with a global audience (>10000 views on YouTube in the last 12 months). The second project is the Animal Behavior Podcast, which the fellow is currently developing with the support of the Animal Behavior Society (coming June 21, 2021). Each episode features conversations with leading researchers in the field of animal behavior, combining discussions of research with professional development, personal experiences, and history of the field.

The fellow will leverage a populations of semi-wild mice to understand the links between individuals’ experience and phenotype, how that phenotype shapes social structure, and ultimately how society influences the individual. First, the fellow will measure the impacts of early life social isolation on individuals’ growth, social behavior, and transcriptome. Second, the fellow will generate populations of semi-wild mice, made up of individuals that experienced social isolation or social connection in early life. The fellow will then use social network analyses to understand the ways in which population-level social structures differ, depending on the early experiences of individuals in the population. Finally, the fellow will use molecular approaches to understand the extent to which the epigenetic consequences of early social experience are transmitted across generations. This research will provide insight into the complex relationships between individual experience, phenotype, and larger social structures in a single study system.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Under this award, I worked as a postdoctoral researcher in collaboration with the Sheehan and Moeller labs at Cornell University, studying the ways in which differences in social experiences have downstream impacts on individuals' physiology, reproduction, sruvival, and the development of their individuality. To do so, I worked in a system in which we study genetically identical lab mice living outside in populations in large semi-natural enclosures.

This approach represents a marriage of the methods and theories of behavioral ecology with the scientific control and infrastructure of the biomedical model organism, the lab mouse. Typically, behavioral ecological studies in wild populations cannot control individuals' social experiences or the demographics of their social environment. This is the tradeoff of studying truly wild animals. On the other hand, studies of lab mice typically take place in an ecologically impoverished environment of the lab, where animals live in small cages without any agency over their movement or social partners, making it impossible to reach strong conclusions about impacts of social experiences that fall in the natural range of experiences.

By studying lab mice outside under semi-natural environments, we are able to capture the best of both of these approaches and reach conclusions about how natural social experiences 'get under the skin' of animals to shape their long-term outcomes. Because these lab mice are essentially genetically identical, we can be confident that differences that we see are the result of social environmental variables that we are able to control rather than any genetic differences.

For example, we showed that for male mice, territorial control is the most important aspect of an individual's life--a behavior that males never get to express in the lab. By assigning some males territories and assigning other males to be territory-less, we showed that males with territories live longer, have better body condition, and have greater access to mates than those males without territories.

In a different experiment, we reared mice from infancy through adulthood and showed that male mice develop their individuality at an earlier age than do females. Using mathematical modeling as well as empirical data streams, we showed that this difference can be explained by the ways in which competition increases the importance of luck in determining individuals' lifetime trajectories. Males in our system experience much higher levels of competition than do females, and they also diverge onto self-reinforcing indiviudal trajectories at an earlier age than do females.

Another important component of my postdoctoral work has been understanding how animals' experience and welfare differs when they live under these more natural conditions as compared to the lab. On the one hand, mortality is higher in the field as animals face many more challenges than they do in the lab. And we've shown that animals age more rapidly at the molecular level as a result of these increased stressors.

But animals also face many more opportunities to live a natural life under these conditions. They have agency over where they move and when. They can control who they interact with. Females get to choose if and when to mate: agency that they completely lack under standard lab conditions. And animals experience so much more dynamism and space in our outdoor conditions, living in a space that is about 9,000 times larger  than a typical mouse cage.

We have some evidence that despite the challenges of living outside, animals are better off for it. They show much lower levels of anxiety on a standard anxiety assay as compared to animals living in the lab. And just a few days of living outside is enough to reduce a lab animal's anxiety to the levels of animals that have been living outside for weeks.

We have published many of these results in peer-reviewed journals already and will continue to do so. But the most important benefit of my postdoctoral experience has been training in an exciting new system in which we are revolutionizing the way that lab mice are studied and behavioral ecology questions can be answered.
